content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I concur with csKingBabar's observation that the puzzle's difficulty level is comparable to other graph-based problems of medium complexity.
approved the contribution

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I agree with csKingBabar, the difficulty of the puzzle is similar to others medium graph based problems.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think it is a nice and enjoyable puzzle and the contribution was improved according to the previous comments! Although I agree that it is an easier medium puzzle, based on the puzzles on the site I disagree with the reject comment that this is too easy for medium puzzle. In complexity it is between the similar graph based problems https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/virus-spreading-and-clustering and https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/death-first-search-episode-1, which are both medium puzzles.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Too easy to be a medium puzzle. Make it an easy puzzle or observe that the firewall would be placed at the end of a bridge , https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bridge_(graph_theory), so you can give N <= 100.000 and maybe make it even a hard puzzle.

Goal section
* Can I just put the firewall on the starting node so that it cannot travel anywhere from there? :D Better to state the restriction.

Constraints section
* Please also state the lower limit of [[L]].

Cases
* Some tests are the same and some validators are the same right now. I assume you are still working on the cases?

Thanks.
Thanks! Of course, you don't want to install a firewall on an infected node. I will add this restriction. Harder test cases are coming up.

Sorry but you are not right. A bridge, in graph theory, is a link whose deletion increases the number of components of the graph. You can easily see from the first example, that the optimal location is not always an end of a bridge, since none of node 3 edges is a bridge. Please reconsider your evaluation accordingly.
I'm sorry not bridges but rather stress points, those can be detected using dynamic conectivity. After deleting a node you can easly verify the number of remaining conex graphs and their sizes.

Exactly. Do you still think this is an easy puzzle in the codingame platform?  I don't have too much experience with the classifications but have seen a few easier puzzles with medium badges. Thanks for the feedback!

The variant where you have dynamic connectivity is hard. But with this constraints where you can just simulate the process for every position of the firewall i don't think the problem has any difficulty. It's a standard bfs or dfs, I don't think this requires any thinking in the brute force way.

Hi O-MEGA,
DFS is a medium difficulty problem in terms of Codin Game puzzle categorization. 
Just a thought.
I didn't use bfs or dfs for solving this :)
I think dfs is the most straight forward idea. Did you use Warshall-Floyd?

The task falls back to identifying the connected components of the graph (after removing every node), as you pointed out right. For finding the connected components I simply assign a unique cluster id for each node in the beginning, iterate through all links of the network and assign the same cluster id for the nodes in the components the link connects. Although similar in spirit, it is neither bfs nor dfs.

The assignment of difficulty level can be highly subjective. So, it's better to rely on more objective criteria. I find the rules of thumb by Wontonimo (another moderator) useful:

(quote begins here)
My rules of thumb for difficulty is as follows : 
* if/else and possibly a loop is 'easy'.  
* Recursion, DFS, BFS, Minimax is 'medium'.  
* Tricky or mathy stuff with multiple steps is 'hard' or 'very hard'
* Very hard: mini research projects requiring a lot of local coding and my own test case development
(quote ends here)

Not saying that they should be strictly applied, but they're good enough to be the starting point for consideration.

I would say this puzzle requires more than simple if/else and loops and qualifies to be Medium. It is fair to say, though, the puzzle is at the easier end of Medium.

@ _O-MEGA, while it is impressive that you have reached Level 30 and finished almost all the CG puzzles of all difficulty levels, they only make up a very small portion of the puzzles available on the CG platform. Solving some community-created puzzles may give you a better feel of how difficulty levels are assigned.
Harder test cases were added.

Thank you for the update.

All sections:
Please use the same variable names as the stub generator.

After that, “Number of nodes” and “Number of links” may be deleted in Constraints section.

Input section
* Please change “A number” to “An integer”.
* Please change “of nodes” to “the number of nodes”.
* Please delete “giving”.
* Please change “of links” to “the number of links”.
* Please change “nodes” to “the indexes of the nodes”

Output section
* Please change “A number” to “An integer”.
* Please change “of the node” to “the index of the node”.
* Please delete “to”.

Constraints section
* The last two pairs of tests and validators (i.e. 4 cases in total) violate the second constraint. Please fix either the cases or the constraint.

* Are all the cases guaranteed to have a unique solution? Please state so if that is the case. Otherwise you have to mention how one should choose the node.

For example, imagine a network where the virus is at #0, and the links are #0-#1, #0-#2, #1-#2, #1-#3, #1-#4, #2-#4 and #2-#5. The best cut may be at node #1 or node #2.

Thanks.
Thanks for the feedback! The description is updated accordingly. The solutions are double-checked to be unique and it is now stated as a final note.

Thank you again! Some minor comments:

Output section
* Please delete "is".

Tags
* It's better to use some previously-used tags instead of new ones (in particular "vaccination" sounds a bit odd in this context). You may refer to the list here:
https://chadok.info/codingame/tags_list.html

Thanks.
Did my best! Thanks!
